name: PDS 70
scenarioDescription:
The PDS 70 Exoplanetary System


Overview

PDS 70 is a star with 0.76 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.26 times its radius. It is located 369.96 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 0.005 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

PDS 70 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the PDS 70 system


PDS 70 b

PDS 70 b was discovered by the Paranal Observatory observatory using the imaging method. Its semi-major axis is 22.00 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of PDS 70 b is 2544 times the mass of Earth. The radius of PDS 70 b is 14.572 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, PDS 70 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


PDS 70 c

PDS 70 c was discovered by the European Southern Observatory observatory using the imaging method. Its semi-major axis is 34.50 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of PDS 70 c is 3335.65782 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, PDS 70 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system PDS 70, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Paranal Observatory.
